review_title: Great organisation let down by poor management
pros: Great colleagues , very warm people. Great ethos and aims for an organisation, very rewarding to feel like you are making a difference to the lives of children and young people. Nice location and flexible hours, no staying late.
cons: Woefully bad Directors. CEO and SMT bluff their way through their jobs and take all the credit of the good work done by middle managers and subordinate staff. Board of Trustees is relatively uninterested in what the day to day staff working in the organisation feel. Upper echelons of the organisation are very outmoded in their outlook and don't allow for any ideas but their own to flourish. Staff morale is generally low and antagonistic towards senior managers due to frustrations. A lot of micromanagement leading to staff turnover and losing good people who are not respected and allowed to flourish in their roles in case they make their Directors look incompetent. Very poor HR.

review_title: Great place to work, but need to develop staff better and pay them consistently
pros:
I really enjoyed working at YoungMinds. This was my first job in the charity sector, and it's a great organisation.

I was developed well at the organisation, I  learned a lot and was given the opportunity to lead on projects and manage my own workload which was exactly what I needed - I had a lot of great experiences at the charity. My manager in particular was very caring, and really pushed me to succeed.

Staff are very friendly, passionate and incredibly knowledgeable. I never dreaded coming to work. The young people the organisation works with are just amazing and a real asset to the place.

Work life balance was great and the HR team are actively making moves to improve this.
cons:
Although my knowledge and skills were developed a lot, my job title and pay did not reflect this and were not increased at the same rate. 

The organisation is still quite small, and there were no opportunities to progress beyond the remit of my role. This is quite common in a few of the teams, Director influence also played a part in this. I took on managing a member of staff but never got any additional pay and little acknowledgement for these duties. 

CEO at the time did not value the efforts, skills and knowledge of the administration staff, and did not recognise the work we did as anything but basic, and therefore refused job title changes and pay increases. The only reason my pay increased after being there for 2 years was because another admin role at a lower level  was being recruited for at a higher salary grade. Discrepancies between my salary and others' at my level was large and dependent on how loudly your Director shouted for it.
